site_title: Great Eastern Q4 earnings down 26%
summary: Great Eastern Holdings Limited reported a 26% decline in Q4 net profit to $165.9 million, primarily due to lower profit from its core insurance business, which fell 23% to $172.1 million. The decline was partly attributed to one-off items, including tax provisions and a change in the timing of terminal bonus recognition. Despite this, operating profit from its core insurance business rose 12% to $559.6 million. The company recommended a final dividend of 40 cents a share and a special dividend of five cents a share.

site_title: Bank Negara's delicate balancing act
summary: Bank Negara, Malaysia's central bank, is maintaining its overnight policy rate at 3% for over 10 quarters to keep the economy growing. However, this accommodative stance has led to a high household debt-to-GDP ratio and potential risks to the financial system. Inflation is expected to rise due to government subsidy rationalization and the introduction of a goods and service tax in 2015. The central bank may raise interest rates this year to narrow yield spreads and prevent a sell-off of Malaysian government securities, which could damage the ringgit.

site_title: High time
summary: The 2014 Salon International de la Haute Horlogerie (SIHH) showcased innovations in the luxury watch industry, with a focus on grand complications. However, the event lacked the buzz of previous years due to the absence of new grand complications from brands like A Lange & Sohne and Audemars Piguet. Instead, brands introduced more affordable luxury watches, with prices decreasing in some cases. Jaeger-LeCoultre unveiled the Master Ultra Thin Minute Repeater, the world's first ultra-thin grand complication, but it only had two complications. The show featured a range of innovative timepieces, including the Van Cleef & Arpels Midnight Planetarium, which combines an astronomic complication with a comet display. The event highlighted the shift towards more affordable luxury watches, with brands like Montblanc and Baume & Mercier offering competitive pricing.

site_title: Longest shipping slump in 3 decades nears end
summary: The shipping industry is emerging from its longest downturn in three decades, driven by an end to overcapacity and growth in bulk commodity cargoes such as iron ore and coal. Dry cargo ships are expected to see the strongest recovery, while tanker rates are also expected to rise due to slowing fleet growth and increased demand in Asia. The global dry bulk seaborne trade is forecast to grow 5.8% this year, outpacing the 5.3% rise in the global merchant fleet.

site_title: 50% more ETFs launched in Jan than in Dec
summary: Exchange-Traded Funds (ETFs) saw a 50% increase in launches in January compared to December, with 42 new funds introduced globally. The majority of these funds (27) were listed in North America, with 25 in the US, and two in Canada. Emerging market exposure was a significant feature, with nine funds having exposure to these markets. Despite investors fleeing emerging markets in January, two new funds aim to filter index constituents to focus on "quality" and "high dividend" paying shares.

site_title: Chia Boon Kuah re-elected as Redas chief
summary: Chia Boon Kuah has been unanimously re-elected as president of the Real Estate Developers' Association of Singapore (Redas) for a two-year term, following his departure from Far East Organisation. His re-election was made possible due to his eligibility as Guocoland's representative on the management committee. Chia expressed his appreciation to committee members for their strong support, and he will now lead the industry body for the current term.

site_title: CapLand to focus China growth efforts in five city-clusters
summary: Capitaland, a Singaporean property developer, is focusing on China's five city-clusters, including Beijing, Shanghai, Guangzhou, Chengdu, and Wuhan, as it marks its 20th year in the country. The company aims to deepen its presence in these clusters, which span across the northern, eastern, southern, western, and central regions of China. This move is seen as part of Capitaland's efforts to capitalize on China's growing property market despite ongoing trade tensions and US tariffs.

site_title: Sun never sets on Empire's musical adventure
summary: Australian singer-songwriter Luke Steele, of Empire of the Sun, is set to return to Singapore for the duo's first-ever headlining show on February 21. The synth-pop duo, known for their critically acclaimed album "Ice On The Dune," has been touring behind the release, which took five years to complete. Steele attributes the album's success to the band's collaborative process and no pressure to live up to expectations, saying "it's really more about raising your own expectations and musical abilities." The show will feature Empire of the Sun's signature visually arresting live performances and catchy dance anthems.

site_title: Tokyo polls to test Japan's rapid swing to the right
summary: Tokyo is set to elect a new governor on Sunday, with the outcome expected to have significant implications for Japan's rapidly shifting political landscape. The election is seen as a test of the country's swing to the right, with Prime Minister Shinzo Abe and two former prime ministers, Juichiro Koizumi and Morihiro Hosokawa, mobilizing to counter the Liberal Democratic Party's (LDP) dominance. The election's outcome will determine whether a credible opposition can be established to challenge the LDP's grip on power, with far-reaching consequences for Japan's domestic politics and diplomatic relations with neighboring countries.

site_title: PCRT distributable income slips 2.5%
summary: PERENNIAL China Retail Trust (PCRT) reported a 2.5% decline in distributable income to $10.9 million for its fourth quarter, down from $11.2 million a year ago. The trust owns and develops shopping malls in China, with revenue from Perennial Jihua Mall, Foshan, increasing to $1.3 million. The full-year amount available for distribution remained unchanged at $43.6 million, largely due to drawdowns from an earn-out fund, which will last until the end of the year.

site_title: One man's trash is another man's treasure
summary: American journalist Adam Minter estimates that billions of dollars worth of scrap materials are generated annually, with China being a major magnet for these resources. Minter has written a book, "Junkyard Planet," highlighting the economic importance of recycling and debunking myths about the industry. Through his reporting, he has witnessed people making fortunes in the business, with manual laborers earning twice as much as office workers. The industry's success is driven by profit, not environmental concerns or good intentions.

site_title: Bringing Indonesian 'archaeologic art' to life
summary: Indonesian artist Yuli Prayitno is showcasing "archaeologic art" that highlights the suppressed culture and history of the Peranakan Chinese in Indonesia. Through his installation-sculptures, Prayitno reassembles and reinterprets artifacts, such as photographs and furniture, to reveal the wisdom and knowledge of the Peranakan Chinese. His work aims to challenge the narrow definition of Indonesian culture under President Suharto and promote multiculturalism. The exhibition, titled "Unity in Diversity: Archaeologic Excavation of the Peranakan Tionghua," has been postponed due to shipment delays.

site_title: Truly, madly, deeply
summary: Concierges at luxury hotels and services share memorable requests, including reuniting a bride with a childhood nanny, arranging a private dinner proposal on Valentine's Day, and creating a custom wedding song CD. These unusual requests showcase the unique services offered by concierge companies, such as Quintessentially Lifestyle and Aspire Lifestyle Asia, which cater to high-end clients' desires and often go above and beyond to create memorable experiences. These services highlight the personal touch and attention to detail that luxury concierges bring to their clients' requests.

site_title: Defence business faces tough environment: Boeing chief
summary: Boeing's defence business faces a tough environment with "flatish" profit margins, according to CEO Jim McNerney. Despite this, the commercial jetliner business is performing well, with room to widen margins due to faster production and better supplier prices. McNerney also acknowledged the need to improve supplier partnerships and invest in engineering and process improvements. Boeing is hiring contract workers to address production issues at the 787 Dreamliner factory and is expected to announce new aircraft orders at an upcoming airshow in Singapore.

site_title: And then there was sound
summary: A "Sound: Latitudes and Attitudes" exhibition at Lasalle College of the Arts in Singapore explores the history of sonic arts in the country, featuring 17 artists and 16 listening stations with diverse sonic creations. Curated by Bani Haykal and Joleen Loh, the exhibition documents the elusive history of sound art in Singapore, which has been largely under the radar of art history. The show highlights the work of artists who transitioned from other mediums, such as sculpture and music, to sound art, and encourages viewers to listen without prejudice.

site_title: Around Town
summary: A musical production of My Fair Lady will be staged at the Sands Theatre in Singapore from February 11 to March 2. The US National Tour features Aurora Florence as Eliza Doolittle and Chris Carsten as Henry Higgins. Meanwhile, Joseph Bone will perform the first installment of his trilogy Bane at the Drama Centre Theatre on February 8 and 9. The Sultan Jazz Club will host Israeli jazz guitarist Yotam Silberstein on February 11 and 12, and an 8-artists exhibition, Lunar New Year 8-Artists Exhibition, will run at the Alliance Francaise de Singapour until February 20.

site_title: This year's arts fest will invoke gods, spirits and legends
summary: This year's Singapore International Festival of Arts will feature a diverse lineup of performances, including a dark and twisted version of Peter Pan by avant-garde director Robert Wilson, a re-performance of Martha Graham's 1963 interview by dancer Richard Move, and a traditional Japanese kyogen act by Mansai Nomura. The festival aims to showcase artistic depth and visual spectacle, challenging the notion that experimental works must be inaccessible to a wider audience. The festival runs from August 12 to September 21, with ticket details to be announced later.

site_title: Revision of registers of electors
summary: Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong has directed the Registration Officer to revise Singapore's registers of electors, which must be completed by March 31, 2014, three years after the last general election in 2011. The Elections Department views the revision as a routine exercise to ensure the registers are up to date. Details on the public inspection of the revised registers will be announced on February 17.

site_title: PEC wins $79m in new contracts
summary: PEC Ltd has secured $79 million in new contracts, contributing to its earnings for the current financial year. The contracts include engineering and construction jobs for a storage facility terminal in Singapore and a liquefied natural gas plant in Malaysia. PEC's orderbook now stands at $176 million. The company's revenue fell 16% to $100.9 million in the quarter ended Sept 30, while its net profit declined 28% to $2.39 million due to increased finance expenses and taxes.

site_title: California critic's book aims to shake up an industry
summary: California wine critic Jon Bonne's new book, "The New California Wine: A Guide to the Producers and Wines Behind a Revolution in Taste," argues that the state's wine industry has prioritized bigger, riper wines over character and elegance. Bonne criticizes the industry's focus on high point scores and exclusivity, instead advocating for a return to the style of the 1970s, when California wines first triumphed over France. He identifies a few holdouts for the old California style, including Paul Draper and Ted Lemon, and praises winemakers who focus on farming and restraint. However, critics argue that the industry's success is due to consumers' acceptance of the Big Flavor style, and that Bonne's movement may be limited to a dedicated minority of wine drinkers.

site_title: Bank of Japan ready to expand monetary stimulus
summary: The Bank of Japan is ready to expand monetary stimulus if external risks undermine its inflation target of 2% due to lacklustre growth in emerging Asia. Deputy governors Kikuo Iwata and Hiroshi Nakaso expressed concerns about the impact of emerging market sell-offs on Japan's exports and economy. Despite this, they stressed that the BOJ will stick to its existing policy, citing solid US growth and expected exports to gradually increase as global demand recovers. The BOJ has kept monetary policy steady since its intense stimulus programme in April last year.

site_title: Swiss property market closer to overheating: UBS
summary: Switzerland's property market is at risk of overheating, according to the UBS Swiss Real Estate Bubble Index, which rose to 1.23 points in the fourth quarter. The market has been fueled by low mortgage rates and high immigration, with price gains outstripping income growth. The Swiss National Bank has maintained zero interest rates, limiting its ability to curb the boom. Experts warn of a potential real estate crisis similar to the 1990s, and the government has increased the countercyclical buffer to 2% for banks to comply.

site_title: Upgrader interest expected at Riverbank @ Fernvale
summary: The sale of Riverbank @ Fernvale, a 555-unit 99-year leasehold private condominium in Sengkang, is set to begin next Friday. The average price per square foot is slightly over $1,000, with prices starting from $476,000 for a one-bedroom unit. Despite falling resale prices, developers remain optimistic about buyer response, citing strong underlying demand and competitive pricing. Experts expect predominantly upgraders and investors to show interest, particularly in smaller units.

site_title: Buying property in Japan with a S'pore bank loan
summary: Singaporeans can now buy property in Japan with financing from local banks, offering up to 95% loan from Bank of China, 70% from UOB, and 50% from OCBC. This shift changes the profile of buyers, who are no longer limited to high-net-worth individuals. With financing available, the number of homes sold to Singapore buyers in Japan is expected to increase, with consultants estimating over 200 sales this year. Properties favored by these buyers are mainly in central Tokyo, with prices starting at $400,000 for one- to two-bedroom units.

site_title: Property sector hopes for the pain to end
summary: Singapore's property sector hopes for easing of cooling measures, which have led to a decline in property prices and foreign investors' participation. The sector's wish is to tweak or remove curbs such as the total debt servicing ratio (TDSR) and additional buyers' stamp duty (ABSD). However, the government is unlikely to make any significant changes, with the earliest relaxation expected in late 2014 or early 2015. Other areas, such as construction and real estate investment trusts (Reits), are also expected to be touched upon in the Budget.

site_title: RHT's India deal raises questions
summary: Religare Health Trust (RHT) has agreed to acquire a clinical facility in Punjab, India, for $55.1 million, sparking questions about the deal's legitimacy. While the acquisition itself is not considered an "interested person transaction," the relationship between RHT's sponsor, Fortis Healthcare, and the facility's vendor, Radha Soami Satsang Beas (RSSB), raises concerns. RSSB is led by a spiritual guru with ties to RHT's CEO and the Dhillon family, who control Fortis Healthcare and Religare Enterprises. RHT's board is expected to provide more clarity on the deal at an upcoming unitholders' meeting.

site_title: A sweet-natured black and white endeavour
summary: Nebraska, a film by director Alexander Payne, tells the story of Woody Grant, an elderly man who believes he has won a million-dollar sweepstakes. His son David accompanies him on a journey to collect the prize, encountering small-town America's quirks and complexities. The film, set in black and white, explores themes of human dignity, family relationships, and the search for meaning. With a talented cast, including Bruce Dern and June Squibb, Nebraska is a sweet-natured endeavour that offers real-life lessons about the human condition.

site_title: Etihad's expansion strategy faces test
summary: Etihad Airlines is considering investing in Alitalia, a move that could test its expansion strategy of acquiring minority stakes in troubled airlines. This would be the airline's largest investment to date, following its purchase of stakes in Air Berlin and other airlines. The deal would be a significant test for Etihad's "airline equity alliance" strategy, which differs from larger regional rivals Emirates and Qatar Airways. The potential investment in Alitalia could also impact the airline's global footprint and its ability to compete with other carriers.

site_title: A mixed bag of big voices
summary: Barbra Streisand's concert album "Back to Brooklyn" celebrates her love for music and her Brooklyn roots. Recorded over two nights in 2012, the album features classics from the Great American Songbook and guest appearances by Chris Botti and Jason Gould. Streisand's voice remains impressive at 71, delivering a rousing performance with a mix of original and altered lyrics. The album is a testament to her enduring passion for music, but excessive stage banter sometimes detracts from the overall experience.

site_title: No hike in toll rates this year, says Muhyiddin
summary: Malaysia's Deputy Prime Minister Muhyiddin Yassin announced that the government will not impose toll-rate increases this year, instead absorbing the RM400 million cost to compensate concessionaires. This decision comes after public pressure over accumulated price hikes due to subsidy rationalisation measures, which have led to a decline in consumer confidence. A by-election is scheduled for March 23, and the outcome is uncertain, with opposition leader Anwar Ibrahim expected to win but the toll rate concession not likely to impact the election.

site_title: StarHub Q4 profit down 4.8%
summary: StarHub's Q4 profit dropped 4.8% to $83.7 million, mainly due to lower equipment sales. Revenue declined 6.2% to $613.7 million. Despite this, the company gained 60,000 new customers and its mobile services segment saw a 0.8% increase in revenue. The pay-TV segment added 2,100 residential customers, while the fixed network services segment saw a 2.8% growth in revenue. The company's full-year net profit grew 3.2% to $370.7 million.

site_title: Thai officials fail to resolve election chaos
summary: Thai officials failed to resolve election chaos after a chaotic weekend ballot disrupted by anti-government protesters. The meeting, which lasted two hours, adjourned without making progress due to "legal issues." Officials stated that those who were unable to vote in affected constituencies have not lost their right to vote, but other issues remain unresolved. The commission will meet again today to address the remaining concerns.

site_title: A dose of daily drama
summary: Singapore's Necessary Stage production "Poor Thing" tackles road rage and social media's impact on behavior, drawing from real-life incidents and audience interactions. The play explores the emotion of anger, without dominating perspectives, and allows audience members to engage with the issue. The production features a video clip of a road accident, social media interaction, and audience movement, making it a unique and accessible experience. The play runs from February 26 to March 2 and March 5 to 9 at The Necessary Stage Black Box.

site_title: Redas-NUS index throws up mixed signals
summary: Developers' sentiment in Singapore's property market improved marginally in Q4 2013, with the Composite Sentiment Index increasing to 4.0 from 3.9. However, 62% of developers anticipate a moderate decrease in residential property prices in the next 6 months, and concerns over rising costs and government cooling measures continue to cap their outlook. The office segment is seen as the best-performing, with developers expressing concerns over land and labour costs.

site_title: No rise seen in local banks' final dividends
summary: Three Singaporean banks - DBS Group Holdings, OCBC Bank, and United Overseas Bank (UOB) - are expected to show no growth in their final dividend payouts for 2013, according to data firm Markit. The banks' stable dividend policy is forecasted to result in flat growth. The telcos remain top performers in the Straits Times Index with yields above 5%. Despite attractive yields, analysts consider it early days to focus on very high yields, with some expecting the banks' yields to reach screaming buys in the future.

site_title: Falling in love with big people is no small feat
summary: A new American black comedy play, Pangdemonium, explores the challenges of falling in love with a larger partner amidst societal pressure for slimness as the only measure of desirability. The play's male protagonist, Tom, faces ridicule from friends and family, while advertisements and media portrayals of beauty reinforce the notion of thinness. The story delves into the complexities of love, societal expectations, and individual identity, raising questions about the impact of external pressures on one's self-perception and relationships.

site_title: A-HTrust posts 3.9% rise in Q3 DPU to 1.61 cents
summary: A-HTrust reported a 33.2% jump in distributable income to $16.6 million in Q3, driven by improved performance of its Australian portfolio, full quarter contribution from Ibis Beijing Sanyuan, and new income from Park Hotel Clarke Quay. DPU rose 3.9% to 1.61 cents. Net property income increased 36.9% to $23.4 million, while gross revenue rose 10.0% to $56.6 million. The trust's Australian hotels achieved a 6-18% increase in revenue per available room, despite a challenging economic climate.

site_title: AbbVie to build US$320m manufacturing facility here
summary: US pharmaceutical firm AbbVie plans to build a $320 million manufacturing facility in Singapore, its first in Asia. The facility, expected to be operational by 2019, will produce drugs for global markets and create over 250 jobs. The company cited Singapore's stable manufacturing environment and collaborative opportunities as reasons for the investment. The facility will be the first in Singapore to combine biologics and small molecules production, supporting AbbVie's "strongest" product pipeline. The move is seen as a significant boost to Singapore's pharmaceutical sector, with the Economic Development Board expecting up to 1,000 new jobs in biologics manufacturing over the next few years.

site_title: Keppel FELS bags first contract this year
summary: Keppel FELS secured its first contract of the year, a US$218 million deal to build a KFELS B class jackup drilling rig for UMW Drilling. This is the third of its kind for UMW Drilling, and the 75th KFELS B class rig ordered since 2000. The rig can operate in water depths of 400 feet and is equipped with accommodation facilities for 150 people. Analysts predict new orders for Keppel this year, with projections of $6 billion to $7 billion, following a record order backlog of $14.2 billion in 2013.

site_title: The Whites have it
summary: Wine expert NK Yong attended the Paulée de Singapour 2014, a charity event featuring 84 wines from Burgundy and Spain. The event highlighted the exceptional quality of the 2010 and 2011 vintages, with 2010 considered one of the greatest Burgundy vintages ever. Yong praised white burgundies, particularly the Chablis Premier Cru Vaillons 2010 and 2011, and Domaine Comte Georges de Vogue's Bourgogne Blanc 2010 and 2011, which he deemed "magnificent" and "irresistible." Other notable white burgundies included the Puligny-Montrachet 1er Cru Les Pucelles 2011 and 2010, and Corton Charlemagne 2011 and 2010 from Domaines Bonneau du Martray, Faiveley, and Louis Jadot.

site_title: Escape if you can, in an hour
summary: A mini industry in Singapore has emerged from reality game entertainment, with "escape room" operators offering fantasy scenarios to customers. The concept, popular in computer games, has grown from one or two operators in the middle of last year to over 10 independent companies with multiple outlets. More are expected to join, with the first hour of the game serving as the time limit to escape before the "captor" returns. This trend showcases the growing demand for immersive entertainment in Singapore.

site_title: Goodbye to Leno is also hello to something better
summary: Jay Leno's 22-year run on NBC's The Tonight Show has come to an end with his final episodes, bringing a close to a era of late-night TV. Leno's farewell has been met with a mix of sentimentality and indifference, with many feeling that his departure is just another chapter in the ongoing "late-night TV wars." As Leno passes the torch to Jimmy Fallon, the conversation shifts towards what's funny now and how viewers prefer to watch television, with a focus on fresh perspectives and new formats. The end of Leno's tenure marks a new era in late-night TV, with a focus on evolving comedy styles and formats.

site_title: Sochi-bound airlines get possible terrorism warning
summary: US airlines flying to Sochi, Russia for the Winter Olympics are being warned to watch for toothpaste tubes containing explosives, which could be used by terrorists. The warning was sent to US and foreign carriers two days before the start of the Games. US Representative Peter King said the threat is real, despite heavy security at the Olympics sites, and urged people to be aware of the danger. The US Department of Homeland Security stated that it is not aware of a specific threat to the homeland, but shares information with international partners to ensure public safety.

site_title: Company Briefs
summary: Otto Marine secured a US$8 million contract for its platform supply vessel Sea Frost, supporting the Atwood Eagle rig in Australia for 152 days. FCL clarified its plans to list a hospitality real estate investment trust (Reit) on the Singapore Exchange, while Tee International signed a non-binding memorandum of understanding with Guangdong Wanlu to explore municipal infrastructure projects in China. NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer was oversubscribed 9.8 times, and Creative Technology warned of potential revenue and operating loss targets.

site_title: Three-Minute Digest
summary: The property sector in Singapore is hoping for a reprieve from cooling measures, with some developers seeking tweaks or rollbacks. The pioneer generation is calling for assistance with MediShield Life premiums. SIA's Q3 profit plummeted 65% to $50.1m, while FJ Benjamin's Q2 earnings halved. The global sukuk market is expected to rebound, exceeding $100bn in issuance. Meanwhile, US watchdogs are near a deal to inspect audit firms in China, and SONY cut 5,000 jobs and exited the PC market.

site_title: FJ Benjamin Q2 net profit halved
summary: FJ Benjamin, an international fashion retailer, reported a 55% drop in Q2 net profit to $586,000, despite an 8% increase in revenue to $104.6 million. The decline was attributed to an exceptional gain from the sale of a Hong Kong property last year. Revenue from South-east Asia rose 13% to $90.2 million, while North Asia revenue dropped 26% due to slowing demand for luxury watches. The company expects positive sales momentum in South-east Asia, driven by strong brands and store openings, but warns of a subdued China market.

site_title: Lightweight look at life in Nazi Germany
summary: The film "The Book Thief" tells the story of Liesel, a 12-year-old girl fostered by the Hubermanns in 1938 Nazi Germany. Narrated by Death, the film explores the themes of mortality, literature, and the impact of war on innocent children. Despite its uplifting tone, the film is criticized for glossing over the Holocaust and treating the subject with kid gloves. The movie focuses on Liesel's relationships with her foster parents and her secret friend Max, a Jewish man hiding in the basement. The film's message about children growing up in times of war is apt, but its delivery is deemed disappointing and one-dimensional.

site_title: Tuas South long-lease industrial site for sale
summary: A 34,189 sq ft long-lease industrial site in Tuas South is for sale by Expression of Interest for $8.9 million. The two-storey building has 39,795 sq ft of gross floor area and 45 years of lease tenure remaining. The site, with a plot ratio of 1.4, is in a Business 2 zone and accessible via the Ayer Rajah Expressway and Pan Island Expressway. It is expected to attract logistics and heavy industrialists, with the sale closing on March 13.

site_title: Surprise expansion in manufacturing
summary: Singapore's manufacturing sector has started 2014 on a strong note, with January's PMI reading of 50.5 beating forecasts and indicating expansion. The sector's growth is attributed to increased new domestic and export orders, as well as a return to growth in output and imports. While some economists believe this trend may continue, others caution that risks to growth remain, including external factors and domestic supply constraints. The electronics PMI also showed a significant jump, with the electronics production sub-index hitting a reading of 55.2, its highest in over a year.

site_title: SingPost's Q3 profit flat on higher costs
summary: SingPost's Q3 net profit remained flat at $39.4 million, despite a 30.2% jump in revenue to $222.6 million, driven by acquisitions and e-commerce growth. The group's logistics division saw a 64.5% increase in quarterly revenue, while costs rose 34.4% due to a change in business model and growth in lower-margin businesses. The company remains vigilant on expenses and focused on cost management and productivity initiatives.

site_title: Anson House put up for sale for $175-180m
summary: CBRE Global Investors has put Anson House, a 13-storey office building in Singapore, up for sale with an indicative price of $175-180 million. The building, which has about 82 years of remaining lease, offers a potential occupier with the option to partly occupy the building, signage, and naming rights. The sale also appeals to core property funds seeking steady rental income and those looking to subdivide the building into individual units. Other notable office buildings in the market include Prudential Tower and Equity Plaza, both also owned by major investors.

site_title: Resale flat COV hits low reached in 2009 crisis
summary: Median cash-over-valuation (COV) premiums for Singapore HDB resale units dropped to $3,000 in January, mirroring a 2009 low during the Global Financial Crisis. Eight HDB towns recorded zero or negative median COV, with Sengkang and Punggol leading the decline. Despite low transaction volumes, the data suggests HDB resale prices are stabilizing. However, the low COV figures may not accurately reflect market conditions due to the limited number of transactions.

site_title: SIA's Q3 profit down 65% due to exceptionals
summary: SINGAPORE Airlines reported a 65% year-on-year decline in net profit to $50.1 million for the third quarter of 2013, driven by exceptional items, share of losses, and one-off items. Revenue remained flat at $3.87 billion, offset by lower yields amid competition and exchange rate movements. The decline was largely due to penalties incurred by SIA Cargo and fines from the Swiss Competition Commission.

site_title: Classical opera child prodigy
summary: Corey Koh, an 11-year-old classical opera singer, is preparing for a solo concert and a performance at the Manhattan School of Music's Summer Voice Festival 2014 in New York City. Despite his young age, he has already gained expertise in acoustics and is seeking a suitable venue. This achievement showcases his exceptional talent and dedication to the art of classical opera.

site_title: S'pore-made satellite to go into orbit next year
summary: ST Electronics plans to launch its first commercial satellite, TeLEOS-1, in the fourth quarter of 2014, marking Singapore's first commercial earth observation satellite. The 400-kg satellite will be launched into a near-equatorial orbit using India's polar satellite launch vehicle and equipped with an electro-optical camera. Partnerships have been formed with Satrec Initiative, SPOT Asia, and US-based Alliant Techsystems (ATK) to distribute satellite imagery and develop microsatellites. The launch is expected to support applications such as disaster and environment monitoring, maritime safety, and homeland security.

site_title: Winter Olympics offer big profit gains to Aeroflot
summary: Russia's Winter Olympics in Sochi are expected to generate higher profits for Aeroflot, the country's largest airline, and Yandex, the largest online search engine service. Aeroflot increased Moscow-to-Sochi flights from five to 15 daily. Despite Moody's Investors Service's doubts about the Olympics' impact on Russia's growth, the games are expected to benefit Aeroflot and Yandex financially.

site_title: Google settles EU probe into search display
summary: Google has settled a 3-year EU antitrust probe after agreeing to display results from rival search services and add new services as long as it grants rival services links next to its search results. The 5-year pledge avoids fines or findings of discrimination against competing search sites. Competitors will pay at least 3 cents to bid for a spot on Google's search pages, addressing EU concerns about Google promoting its specialist services and stifling competition. The deal closes a high-profile case for EU Competition Commissioner Joaquin Almunia, who seeks similar settlements before leaving office.

site_title: Canadian parents helping finance kids' homes
summary: Canadian parents are increasingly helping their children buy homes, with 27% of first-time buyers expecting parental aid in a 2013 survey. Home prices have soared 84% in 10 years, making it difficult for most buyers to afford. Many experts say this trend is common in priciest markets like Toronto, with at least 50% of buyers receiving parental assistance. Parents are helping with downpayments, allowing young buyers to focus on mortgage payments, and some even see it as a way to pass on wealth while alive.

site_title: Insurers' asset sale gains not always taxable, court rules
summary: Singapore's Court of Appeal has ruled that gains from the sale of assets held by regulated insurance companies in insurance funds mandated by the Insurance Act are not automatically taxable income. The court determined that the reason for holding the assets needs to be first determined, with gains from assets held for trade purposes considered taxable and those held for long-term strategic interests considered capital and not taxable. This judgment confirms the principle that regulatory rules have little impact on taxation rules.

site_title: Premium of re-classified small car COE stays firm
summary: The premium for re-classified small car COEs in Singapore remained firm, with Category A staying above $70,000. Dealers of Korean and Japanese cars made strong bids, attributed to anticipation of the February re-categorization. Category B and E premiums also fell, while Category C and D increased. The move to re-classify Cat A was to keep luxury models out, but dealers expect Cat A to eventually soften as prices rise, and Cat B premiums to increase in the next round.

site_title: Company Briefs
summary: Blumont Group's proposed acquisition of 135 million shares by chairman-designate Alexander Molyneux has been deferred due to technical issues. United Envirotech has issued $35 million of fixed-rate notes due 2016. Manhattan Resources is being sued by former executive director Lee Kok Choy, who claims he was not paid for work as nominee director. NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer was oversubscribed 9.8 times.

site_title: Using digital investments to grow business
summary: A survey of 1,041 C-suite executives across 20 countries and 12 industries found that businesses with proper digital investments are likely to experience growth. The majority of companies focus on improving internal costs and driving productivity, but Singapore executives prioritize selling new products and services, and investing in research and development. Optimism is returning to global markets, with 76% of executives expecting profits to increase and 65% planning to expand their workforce. However, cost challenges, such as raw material costs and high capital costs, are tempering growth ambitions in Singapore.

site_title: LNG may soon overtake oil as main ship fuel
summary: Natural gas is poised to challenge oil as the main ship fuel, driven by cheaper gas and stricter environmental regulations. Companies are building gas-powered ships and installing networks of service stations on water and land. Analysts expect LNG prices to drop substantially later this decade, making it a cleaner alternative to oil-based fuels. Germany, Singapore, and the Netherlands are investing in natural gas transport hubs, while companies like Royal Dutch Shell and Gazprom are developing LNG fuel infrastructure. Global gas demand in the transport sector is expected to grow from under 5 billion cubic meters in 2012 to over 160 billion cubic meters by 2030.

site_title: Three-Minute Digest
summary: Singapore's manufacturing sector started 2014 on a strong note, with an improvement in January's purchasing managers' index. Insurance firms' asset sales may not be taxable, according to a Court of Appeal ruling. The premium for a re-classified small car COE stayed above $70,000, and Asian central banks face challenges in steadying economies. Environment-related companies benefited from China's worsening environmental crisis, while Credit Suisse expects an acceleration in mergers and acquisitions globally.

site_title: Peruvian bets big with acquisition of iconic Detroit eyesore
summary: Peruvian developer Fernando Palazuelo has acquired the iconic Detroit Packard Motor Car plant for $405,000, a 15-cent-per-square-foot price tag for a 16-hectare site. Palazuelo plans to transform the dilapidated plant into a mixed-use development over the next 10 years, requiring an estimated $350 million in investment. His strategy involves methodically rebuilding parts of the site over time, a unique approach in Detroit's land rush of investors seeking to buy vacant properties at discounted prices.

site_title: Westgate Tower put up for lease by new owners (Amended)
summary: Westgate Tower, a 20-storey office block in Jurong East, is back on the leasing market after new owners, Sun Venture-Low Keng Huat, exercised options to buy the property at $579.4 million ($1,900 psf). The asking rent is around $6.50 psf, down from initial indications of $8 psf. This follows similar trends in nearby developments, such as The Metropolis and Venture Avenue, where rents are also decreasing. The office block features Grade A specifications and efficient column-free space.

site_title: Mizuho eyeing Australia commercial property
summary: Mizuho Bank Ltd, Japan's third-largest lender, is considering expanding its commercial real estate lending in Australia, aiming to top its $2.5 billion syndicated loan in the South Pacific last year. The bank's Sydney branch general manager, Debra Hazelton, said Mizuho wants to be more active in commercial property lending in Australia, particularly among its existing customers. This move comes as the bank seeks to broaden its Australian business amid heightened rivalry and a cooling mining boom.

site_title: Sony in talks to sell Vaio Japan to fund
summary: Sony is in talks to sell its Vaio Japan operations to Japan Industrial Partners, a Japanese fund, to fund its exit from the loss-making computer business as part of its restructuring efforts. This move comes as Sony aims to focus on its TV division, which has lost $7.5 billion over the last 10 years, and to catch up with local peers Panasonic and Sharp. Sony's PC business, which has been struggling, is expected to report an operating loss of around 30 billion yen in the year through March 2014.

site_title: Airbus to offer India assembly to clinch C295 military plane order
summary: Airbus plans to bid on a contract to supply 56 military transport planes to the Indian Air Force, with the potential to establish a local assembly line in India. The company aims to boost business outside the US and Europe, with the Indian market offering "enormous" potential. Airbus is also seeking to supply transport aircraft to the Indian Coast Guard and has previously been named preferred bidder for an air-to-air refuelling contract. The Indian government has eased its offset policy to allow more time for foreign defense companies to meet rules, and Airbus has provided technical advice on the country's light combat aircraft project.

site_title: May 2 opening of KLIA2 unlikely
summary: Malaysia's new budget terminal KLIA2's May 2 opening is unlikely due to its main contractor's failure to secure the certificate of completion and compliance (CCC). A report found that 65% of the main terminal failed fire and safety checks, and sewage issues were also discovered. The delay pushes back the operational-readiness and airport-transfer (Orat) process, which was initially set for May 2. The main priority is public safety, with proper rectification works to be carried out.

site_title: London's office space shortage sparks interest in older buildings
summary: London's office space shortage is driving investors to seek older buildings for refurbishment, with developers and investors looking to capitalize on the supply and demand imbalance. Investors, including Blackstone Group LP and Brookfield Office Properties Inc, are purchasing and renovating office buildings from the 1980s and early 1990s, with prices and rents increasing due to the shortage. The strategy allows for faster lease-ups and higher profits, with some investors expecting to make at least £20 million from refurbishments. Rising demand and expected rent increases of at least 10% a year through 2016 are attracting buyers, particularly from overseas, for prime office space in the City.

site_title: Backlog helps Boeing cut currency risks
summary: Boeing says its large 737 jet order backlog will cushion it against currency market turmoil, allowing it to keep factories busy for seven years. The backlog of 3,680 orders is strong in terms of quantity, financial strength of customers, and global reach, according to Boeing Vice-President Beverly Wyse. Despite concerns about emerging market currencies, Boeing forecasts continued strong demand for its 737 models and plans to boost production to 52 jets a month by the end of the decade.

site_title: IPOs take a back seat in rocky stock market
summary: The Singapore stock market's volatility has led to a slowdown in initial public offerings (IPOs), with January's four listings raising $433.3 million in gross proceeds but seeing mixed fortunes. The market's decline, coupled with concerns over emerging markets and the US Federal Reserve's quantitative easing program, has made it challenging for companies to attract cornerstone investors. As a result, IPO pricing is under pressure, and the market's uncertainty may continue to affect IPO activity in the coming months.

site_title: Del Monte buying over US namesake business
summary: Del Monte Pacific is selling minority stakes to boost its funds for the purchase of a US food company of the same name. Meanwhile, SunMoon Food Company is buying into a US-based beverage maker. The deals are part of the companies' efforts to expand their global footprints. Del Monte Pacific will receive US$37.25 million from two investors, while SunMoon Food Company will invest in a US kids' drinks maker. The moves aim to strengthen the companies' presence in the global market.

site_title: Google barge with no permit may have to leave
summary: Google's mystery barge, under construction on a pier at a former Navy base in San Francisco, may be forced to leave due to lack of permits. The Treasure Island Development Authority, running the property, does not have authority to issue permits for the pier, despite Google's use of it. The state commission has sent a letter to TIDA, stating that no permits were issued for the project, and the issue can be resolved by moving the barge or obtaining a permit. Google is using shipping containers to turn the barge into an event space and marketing vessel.

site_title: DBS, OCBC see jump in brand value
summary: DBS and OCBC have improved their global brand ranking among lenders, with DBS ranking 54th and OCBC 81st, driven by double-digit growth in brand value. UOB, however, fell two spots to 89th after experiencing tepid growth. The three local banks collectively have a total brand value of US$8.5 billion, with DBS leading with a brand value of US$4 billion.

site_title: Asian central banks forced to do their governments' job
summary: Asian central banks are taking on more responsibility for their countries' economic stability as governments fail to implement necessary reforms. Countries such as India, Indonesia, and Thailand have implemented emergency measures to shore up their economies, but governments have not addressed underlying issues like inflation and market rigidities. Central banks are detouring from their price and financial stability mandates to fill the void, raising concerns about the risk of delayed reforms and financial imbalances. Japan and China are also relying heavily on central banks, with some experts warning that markets could reverse and economies could face stagflation if fundamental reforms are not implemented.

site_title: Uptick in M&As likely in 2014: Credit Suisse
summary: Credit Suisse predicts an uptick in mergers and acquisitions (M&As) globally in 2014, driven by European and American firms seeking to reduce debt. Asian banking and insurance sectors are expected to consolidate, with Japanese and Chinese companies identified as potential acquirers. The report notes that 70% of US companies with low net debt are in the market cap, but cautions that credit-market debt may not accurately reflect corporate leverage. This trend is expected to filter into Asia, potentially leading to increased M&A activity.

site_title: US airlines' on-time data incomplete: govt report
summary: The US Department of Transportation's inspector-general report found that only 76% of domestic flights at commercial airports are accounted for in the government's on-time statistics, leaving a significant gap in reporting. This incomplete data affects flights operated by regional carriers and Spirit Airlines, as well as smaller planes more likely to be delayed or cancelled. A proposed rule to improve accuracy has been delayed for over two years, prompting passenger advocates to express frustration.

site_title: Cashing in on environmental woes of China
summary: China's worsening environmental crisis is driving investment opportunities for environment-related companies worldwide. The government's 12th five-year plan, announced in 2011, includes a $628 billion investment to combat air and water pollution. This has led to increased demand for pollution control, renewable energy, and environmental protection equipment. Companies in these sectors are rushing to help Beijing, with some even eyeing higher fees for services. As a result, businesses are capitalizing on China's environmental woes, presenting a significant business opportunity.

site_title: Singapore Airshow: a much-valued platform
summary: The Singapore Airshow, a biennial event, is set to begin, bringing together military and commercial aviation industries in one location. The event attracts over 1,000 companies, including 60 top aerospace companies, for partnerships and business opportunities. This year's airshow follows the record-breaking Dubai Airshow in November, where orders reached nearly $200 billion. Expect muted order flows in Singapore due to the strong presence of Gulf carriers.

site_title: SRC goes ahead with long-delayed upgrading
summary: Singapore Refining Company (SRC) has received the green light for a US$500 million-plus upgrading project on Jurong Island, a long-delayed expansion aimed at boosting competitiveness in the global refining market. The project includes a "green" gasoline facility and cogeneration plants to cater to growing clean fuel requirements and improve energy efficiency. The upgrade is expected to help SRC's 290,000 barrel-per-day refinery stay competitive amid current overcapacity.

site_title: Will new Microsoft CEO be a change agent?
summary: Microsoft's new CEO, Satya Nadella, has been described as a change agent with a proven track record of driving innovation, particularly in the cloud and enterprise space. However, his ability to drive change and challenge tradition will be crucial to his tenure at the top of the company. Analysts praise Nadella's abilities and intellect, but his willingness to make radical choices is what will make or break his leadership. His success will depend on his ability to balance innovation with respect for tradition and tradition.

site_title: Struggling Merpati grounds all flights
summary: Indonesia's PT Merpati Nusantara Airlines has grounded all flights until at least the end of February due to financial struggles, including a debt of over 6 trillion rupiah. The airline has not paid salaries for three months and is exploring options such as selling assets and converting debt to equity. Route permits have been suspended, and the government has decided not to provide further loans to the airline, which has assets worth only 300 billion rupiah.

site_title: Three-Minute Digest
summary: Stock markets in Asia and the US experienced a decline, with Japan's Nikkei 225 falling 4.2% to a four-month low. The region's plunge was triggered by a steep overnight loss on Wall Street. Issuers are expected to wait for the market to calm down before going ahead with initial public offerings. Telcos are battling for market share in Singapore's app wars, while DBS and OCBC Bank have risen in the global brand ranking among lenders. Indonesia is expected to increase payments on its sukuk bonds, and Reliance Industries is set to enter the voice market in India.

site_title: Surprises unlikely in S'pore banks' Q4 results: analysts
summary: Singapore banks' Q4 results are expected to be uneventful, with analysts predicting no surprises. The results, released on Valentine's Day, will focus on the banks' strong loan growth in 2013, rather than factors like tapering and the Thai political situation. Analysts believe these factors will not be reflected in the results, which will be influenced by the banks' resilience in the economy.

site_title: Southwest sees challenge to American in Dallas
summary: Southwest Airlines is expanding nonstop flights from Dallas's Love Field airport, the largest low-fare carrier's biggest hub, by offering trips to LaGuardia in New York, Reagan National in Washington, and eight other cities. The expansion, starting October 13, will increase competition with American Airlines, the largest carrier at Dallas-Fort Worth International Airport. Southwest's CEO Gary Kelly expects lower fares due to the increased competition, saying "There is no way the fares won't come down." The move is seen as a positive for Southwest, while American Airlines may face a negative impact.

site_title: India's top priority is to revive stalled projects
summary: India's government is prioritizing reviving stalled projects to boost economic growth amid high inflation and weak currency. The Reserve Bank of India (RBI) recently raised the benchmark repo rate to 8% to tackle inflation, but industry analysts criticized the move as it may delay economic recovery. RBI Governor Raghuram Rajan emphasized the need to revive stalled projects, citing a decline in investment in new factories and assets. The government's efforts to fast-track stalled projects, such as those led by the Cabinet Committee on Investments, are seen as a step towards reviving the economy.

site_title: Private equity deals continue decline
summary: Private equity deal-making in the Asia-Pacific ex-Japan region declined 46% in 2013 to US$11.4 billion, the lowest annual period since 2005. However, selected South-east Asian countries such as Singapore, Malaysia, and the Philippines saw growth in PE investments. China remained the largest beneficiary, attracting US$4.5 billion, while India and South Korea followed. The largest sectors for PE investments were industrial and energy-related companies and internet-related companies, accounting for 27% and 24% of the total investments, respectively.

site_title: Auction of Chinese artwork raises $226,000 for charities
summary: A charity auction of a Chinese calligraphic work at the Ritz Carlton Millenia Singapore raised $226,000 for two local charities. The artwork, measuring 5x2 feet, was created by calligraphy master Phang Weng Kiong and Wee Ee Cheong, deputy chairman of UOB Group. The winning bid of $113,000 was placed by UOB customer Derrick Ong, with the bank matching the bid and donating the funds to The Straits Times School Pocket Money Fund and The Business Times Budding Artists Fund.

site_title: Don't blame the Fed for everything
summary: The US Federal Reserve's quantitative easing (QE) programs, which expanded its balance sheet to $4 trillion between 2008 and 2013, have been blamed for the collapse in emerging markets (EMs) in 2014. However, a more nuanced view suggests that the Fed cannot be held solely responsible for the EM problems, as the slowdown in China, internal economic issues, and structural weaknesses in EMs have contributed to the selling. The Fed's tapering of QE, which began in 2013, was not the sole cause of the EM selloff, and the markets had already known that the "punch bowl" of monetary support would eventually be taken away.

site_title: Factory orders fall in Dec due to drop in transport bookings
summary: US factory orders fell 1.5% in December due to a drop in transportation bookings, the largest decline since July. Excluding transportation, orders rose 0.2% for the third consecutive month. Despite a slowdown in factory activity, order backlogs remain high, and economists expect manufacturing to slow down early this year. The ISM survey reported a low in January, but bad weather and payback from the previous quarter's robust growth are contributing factors.

site_title: Lotte gets Singapore nod for mall Reit: report
summary: Lotte Shopping, South Korea's largest mall owner, has gained regulatory approval for an initial public offering (IPO) in Singapore. The IPO could raise up to US$1 billion and will test investors' appetite for a trust containing some of its shopping malls. Despite market volatility and concerns about yield instruments, experts believe Lotte's strong fundamentals and growing demand for real estate investment trusts (Reits) will support the listing. The Singapore Exchange (SGX) declined to comment on the deal.

site_title: Sell-off in EM assets overdone: UBS CEO
summary: UBS CEO Sergio Ermotti warns that the sell-off in emerging-market assets may be "overdone" amid a $6.3 billion outflow from developing-nation stocks in the week through Jan 29. This has led to the MSCI Emerging Markets Index's valuation dropping to 11 times reported earnings, a 40% discount against the MSCI World Index. Global investors are pulling money from emerging markets due to slowing economies, weak currencies, and interest rate hikes. Ermotti cautions that not all emerging markets have the same prospects, and differentiation is key in investment decisions.

site_title: EMs see the 'dark side' of foreign investments
summary: Turkey's central bank raised interest rates to 10% to quell currency fluctuations, but the move was short-lived as the lira lost value again. The country's economic woes are linked to corruption investigations and a construction-driven growth model, which has led to a surge in current-account deficits and capital outflows. Other emerging markets, such as Brazil, India, and Indonesia, are also at risk due to similar fundamental issues, with Morgan Stanley and Gluskin Sheff identifying them as the most exposed. A cycle of capital inflows and outflows is expected, with short-term debt and foreign exchange reserves posing significant risks.

site_title: Basel III changes M&A appetite for banks
summary: Basel III regulations have reduced banks' appetite for minority stakes in fellow lenders, making it more expensive for them to hold minority shares exceeding 10%. This poses challenges for banks looking to gain a foothold in Asean through mergers and acquisitions. Higher capital requirements also mean banks are unlikely to hold long-term assets, and systems upgrades to meet regulatory requirements are eating into profits. Regulators are exploring regulatory harmonization, but it's unclear if the Volcker Rule, aimed at restricting proprietary trading, will be implemented in Singapore.

site_title: Port Hedland's iron ore exports to China up
summary: Iron ore exports from Australia's Port Hedland to China rose 27% in January, reaching 23.3 million tonnes, the highest level in 16 months. Total iron ore exports were 28.2 million tonnes, with shipments to China totaling 24.2 million tonnes. The global ore market remains undersupplied, and prices are expected to decline further due to expanding supply. Major miners, such as Rio Tinto and Fortescue, are increasing production and capacity to meet growing demand.

site_title: Telcos move battle to mobile app turf
summary: Telcos in Singapore are intensifying their battle for mobile app dominance, with StarHub signing an exclusive partnership with Japan's Line for its pre-paid customers. Starting February 15, pre-paid users will have access to Line plans at $0.40 per day or $6 for 30 days. This move aims to capitalize on the growing mobile data use in Singapore's pre-paid market, according to StarHub's head of mobility.

site_title: Regional M&A activity to pick up in 2014
summary: Regional M&A activity is expected to grow in 2014, driven by interest in the energy, resources, and infrastructure sectors. WongPartnership, the top-ranking Singapore law firm by deal count in 2013, is optimistic about the M&A space this year. The firm's head, Andrew Ang, noted that the region's stability will depend on the political fabric of countries such as Thailand, which could impact Singapore's growth.

site_title: Amazon airports seen cutting cargo-haul times
summary: Brazil's government plans to build remote airports to boost air traffic and reduce cargo transport costs, which are twice the US average. The US$3 billion plan aims to end dependence on Amazon River and road transport. Auctions for operating 270 regional airports will start in April, with subsidies offered to construct airports and airlines to add regional routes, providing a "big stimulus" for Embraer SA.

site_title: Yongnam consortium back in the running for Myanmar airport
summary: Yongnam Holdings' consortium, consisting of Changi Airport Planners and Engineers and Japan's JGC Corporation, has been invited to bid on Myanmar's Hanthawaddy International Airport project after an unsuccessful attempt last year. The consortium, which includes a 30-year public-private partnership agreement, will enter into negotiations on design, construction, operation, and maintenance of the airport. The estimated value of the project is around US$1 billion, and the company hopes for a successful conclusion but warns shareholders to exercise caution.

site_title: Picking future marine fuels
summary: The maritime industry is shifting towards alternative fuels as the International Maritime Organization imposes stricter regulations on greenhouse gas emissions and air pollution. Classification society DNV GL predicts that liquefied natural gas (LNG) will be an early success, while hybrid propulsion solutions and nuclear energy may also play a role in the future. Residual fuel oil, despite its high sulphur content, is not entirely ruled out, with DNV GL citing its potential well-to-propeller greenhouse emissions as a factor in its evaluation. The transition to sustainable fuels will pose challenges for shipowners, who must adopt new technologies and consider the availability of alternative fuels.

site_title: Rex jumps on news of Oman hydrocarbon find
summary: Rex International's shares rose 8% to 65 cents after a joint-venture unit found hydrocarbons in a second exploration well in Oman using the firm's virtual drilling technology. The discovery comes after a setback in its first exploration well, where drilling was stopped due to mud losses. Rex's technology allows for direct identification of hydrocarbons, boosting its success rate to over 50%. The discovery is seen as a significant step towards the deepening of knowledge on Oman's offshore geology.

site_title: Lenovo shares slump 16% after downgrade by brokers
summary: Lenovo shares plummeted 16% after being downgraded by at least five brokerages, with its market value cutting $2.2 billion. The tech giant's acquisition of Motorola Mobility and IBM's low-end server unit were criticized for adding unprofitable businesses and increasing competition. Analysts expect Motorola Mobility to lose money for the next three years, weighing on Lenovo's earnings. The company's shares were downgraded to neutral by UBS and Morgan Stanley, with a price forecast of HK$10.30 from HK$12. Lenovo's PC shipments have slumped, with the global market experiencing its worst year ever in 2013.

site_title: Wall St dive extends sell-off in Asia markets
summary: Stock markets in Asia plummeted yesterday, led by Japan's 4.2% drop, its worst performance in four months. The losses were triggered by a steep decline on Wall Street, with the US manufacturing data and federal debt ceiling concerns contributing to the downturn. The yen's rise also hurt Japanese exporters, while the US yield on the 10-year Treasury fell to 2.6%, mirroring its level during a previous government shutdown. Brokers predict a prolonged sell-off, citing the withdrawal of monetary stimulus from the US Federal Reserve.

site_title: TripAdvisor redesigns site to break down cost of airline seats
summary: TripAdvisor is redesigning its flights search feature to provide detailed information on flight prices, including added charges for options like extra legroom, as well as in-flight amenities. The feature will be localized for 31 countries and 17 languages, aiming to simplify the complex shopping experience for travelers. The redesign will also include fare comparisons, seat pitch, and availability of amenities like Wi-Fi and power ports. The move is in response to the growing demand for easily accessible comparison-shopping information and the complexity of airline options.

site_title: Alitalia stake decision soon: Etihad
summary: Etihad Airways plans to decide within 30 days whether to invest in struggling Italian airline Alitalia, with Italian Prime Minister Enrico Letta stating his government won't impose conditions on the deal. The investment could bring "a shot in the arm" for Alitalia, allowing it to adopt Etihad's best practices and receive financial support.

site_title: Otto Marine sells two vessels for US$30m
summary: Otto Marine has sold two 61m work-maintenance vessels to its associate Go Marine Services for US$30 million, generating an estimated net gain of US$6.4 million. The vessels were valued at US$32 million by a third-party independent valuation report. The sale proceeds will be used to repay bank loans, improving the group's working capital. The transaction follows a six-month charter agreement between Otto Marine and Go Marine Services, with the associate meeting its purchase obligation.

site_title: Two US airlines halt code-share with India's Jet
summary: US airlines United Airlines and American Airlines have halted code-share agreements with Jet Airways (India) due to the Federal Aviation Administration's (FAA) downgrade of India's aviation-safety ranking to Category 2. The downgrade bars Indian carriers from starting new US flights and requires additional inspections in the US. India's Civil Aviation Minister expressed disappointment, but the Indian government has made progress in addressing safety concerns. The FAA has offered to help India regain its Category 1 rating.

site_title: Citigroup sanguine about Asean despite social tensions
summary: Citigroup remains optimistic about the economic prospects of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (Asean), despite social tensions and risks. The bank's head of Asean, Michael Zink, cited the progress made in creating standardized cross-border trade rules and the growth of the region's capital markets as key factors. Zink highlighted the Asean Single Window initiative, which aims to speed up cargo clearance, as a major opportunity for Citi to tap into intra-Asean trade. However, social tensions, including income inequality and labor concerns, pose challenges to the region's economic integration.

site_title: Government steps in to ease shortage of granite
summary: The Singapore government has released granite from its national stockpile to ease a shortage caused by Indonesian granite exports being blocked. The shortage has affected private and public construction projects, with the Building and Construction Authority urging the industry to diversify its sources. The release will benefit main contractors with ongoing projects requiring granite, and is expected to "further ease the situation" until regional supply sources can ramp up.

site_title: M1 mobile users hit by disruptions
summary: M1 mobile users experienced intermittent disruptions in service, including voice calls, text messages, and mobile data, on Tuesday. The issue was resolved by 12:15pm, with the telco attributing it to a call processing software issue. M1 has apologized and will give customers one day of free local calls and SMS services on Sunday. The Infocomm Development Authority of Singapore has expressed concern and will conduct its own investigation, potentially leading to a fine under the Service Resiliency Code.

site_title: Budget carrier flydubai eyes bond issue in 2015
summary: Flydubai, a Dubai-based budget carrier, plans to raise funds through a bond issue in 2015, with a potential sukuk (Islamic bond) option. The company aims for a $500 million benchmark-sized offer to finance general operating expenses and aircraft deliveries. Flydubai has ordered 150 Boeing 737-MAX jets and has been relying on aircraft sale and lease-back arrangements, direct bank loans, and other financing options to pay for plane deliveries. The move is seen as a diversification of financing and a way to reduce reliance on debt markets.

site_title: Romanians reject euro home loans after Hungary disaster
summary: Romania has implemented a government-backed loan guarantee program to stabilize the housing market, which has been devastated by the economic crisis. The program guarantees 50% of mortgages worth up to €75,000, with a 5% down payment, to protect borrowers from exchange rate fluctuations. The program aims to reduce the risks for banks and make cheaper loans available to first-time homebuyers. The move follows Hungary's experience with foreign-currency loans, which led to a slump in the forint currency.

site_title: EMs: No big dent on world economy
summary: Emerging market (EM) currencies have experienced volatility in 2014, with the US Federal Reserve's quantitative easing taper and growing concerns about China's growth contributing to the sell-off. The "Fragile Five" countries, including South Africa, Turkey, Brazil, India, and Indonesia, are particularly vulnerable to economic shocks due to their reliance on foreign capital. However, the impact on the global economy is expected to be limited, with the G-3's exposure to stressed EM economies at around 2%. China's large economy and significant exports to EMs are also expected to help calm the markets, and global growth recovery remains unchanged.

site_title: Company Briefs
summary: Swiber Holdings secured five contracts worth US$235 million, including three in Latin America and South-east Asia. SP AusNet's euro bond issue met strong demand, oversubscribed four times. STRATECH Systems won a contract to upgrade Changi airport's surveillance system. Otto Marine promoted executive director Michael See and appointed new CFO Denville Wee.

site_title: UBS reports big switch back into profit
summary: Swiss bank UBS reported a significant turnaround in its financial performance, posting a net profit of 3.2 billion Swiss francs (S$4.49 billion) in 2013, up from a loss of 2.4 billion francs in 2012. The bank attributed the improvement to a massive reorganization and adaptation to a new Swiss banking climate. Key highlights include a 17% increase in pre-tax profit for the wealth management arm, 2.5 billion francs in pre-tax profit for the investment bank division, and 917 million francs in net profit for the fourth quarter.

site_title: China figures point to economy slowing down
summary: China's official services sector Purchasing Managers Index (PMI) fell to a five-month low in January, confirming the country's economy is slowing down. The non-manufacturing PMI decreased to 53.4, while the business expectations sub-index dropped to 58.1, the lowest reading since February 2009. These declines indicate the government's ongoing reform plans are affecting the economy. China's economic slowdown is a concern for the world's second-largest economy, with implications for global trade and growth.

site_title: China home price gains slow in Jan, surveys show
summary: China's home prices slowed in January, with new homes rising 9.39% from a year earlier, the slowest gain in nine months. This easing marks the first slowdown since January 2013, as local governments tightened property market curbs. Despite this, prices remain at record highs, and speculation suggests continued growth in major cities. Official home prices data for 70 major cities will be released on February 24.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Oxley Holdings announced a net income of S$250.8 million in Q1FY14, a 37 times year-over-year increase, surpassing the combined earnings of CapitaLand and City Developments. This marks a significant growth for the company.

site_title: Results of productivity push under question
summary: The Productivity and Innovation Credit (PIC) scheme in Singapore, introduced in 2010, is under scrutiny for its effectiveness in boosting productivity levels. Despite significant spending, the take-up rate among smaller firms remains low, prompting calls for tweaks to the existing schemes to enhance their efficacy. The focus is on improving the PIC scheme, which offers 400% tax deductions and cash payouts for productivity-related investments. Businesses are seeking modifications to boost its potency, rather than additional help through new schemes.

site_title: Manufacturing growth slows in January
summary: US manufacturing activity slowed in January, with the Institute for Supply Management's (ISM) factory index decreasing to 51.3 from 56.5, the weakest pace in eight months. New export orders declined for the first time since October, and production and bookings also slowed. The decline was attributed to cold weather and weakness in emerging markets. Despite this, the outlook for the rest of the year remains solid, with sustained gains in consumer purchases, labor market improvement, and capital spending needed to maintain factory activity.

site_title: STI falls below support level of 3,000 points
summary: Singapore's benchmark Straits Times Index (STI) fell below the 3,000-point psychological support level, closing at 2,990.95 points, down 1.2% from the previous day. Analysts remain confident of a rebound, citing sound fundamentals such as a recovering global economy and a stable Singapore dollar. Key support levels include 2,980 and 2,960 points, but analysts expect the STI to hold around the 3,000 level, with some predicting a medium-term rebound to 3,000-3,500 points by year-end.

site_title: RHT in deal to buy hospital in northern India
summary: Religare Health Trust (RHT) has entered into agreements worth $68.8 million with Fortis Healthcare to acquire a hospital facility in northern India, Mohali Clinical Establishment, for 2.7 billion rupees. The acquisition is expected to add 355 beds to RHT's portfolio and strengthen its presence in the region. Fortis Healthcare, which owns 27.9% of RHT, aims for the transactions to be yield-accretive to unitholders, with an estimated increase in pro forma distribution per unit from 3.55 cents to 3.75 cents.

site_title: United to cut flights from Cleveland
summary: United Continental Holdings plans to significantly reduce flights from its unprofitable Cleveland hub, cutting average daily departures by 60% starting in April. This reduction will result in 36% less capacity based on seats and may lead to up to 430 airport operations staff and 40 catering personnel losing their jobs. The decision was accelerated by a pilot shortage due to new federal regulations requiring more flight experience from pilots. United will maintain pilot and flight attendant bases, technical operations, and keep its headquarters in Chicago.

site_title: Company Briefs
summary: Construction firms secure multi-million dollar contracts. Lian Beng Group clinches a $117 million contract to construct a multi-storey building, while Wee Hur Holdings secures a $103.6 million HDB project in Sengkang. Logistics Holdings bags a $31.7 million contract from the HDB for electrical substations and switch rooms. Tritech Group's subsidiary receives an $8.1 million contract from the Land Transport Authority for instrumentation and monitoring services. These deals are expected to have a positive financial impact on the respective companies' earnings and order books.

site_title: Aussie home prices up 1.2% in Jan
summary: Australian home prices rose 1.2% in January, extending a strong run that boosted household wealth and confidence. Overall dwelling prices were up 9.8% compared to January last year, led by a 13.4% jump in Sydney and 11.9% in Melbourne. Home values are now 4.8% higher than their previous peak in October 2010.
